title: How to Make Saffron Rice Pudding

steps.headline: Cover the uncooked rice with warm water in a pot.
Stir the rice gently in the water.
steps.description: Stirring helps to remove some of the starch and grit

steps.headline: Rinse and drain the rice several times, until the water runs clear.
Drain the washed rice.
Place the rice in a non-stick saucepan with 10 cups of water and a 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
Place the saffron into 2 tablespoons of warm water and set aside to infuse.
Cover the rice with a lid.
Bring the rice to a boil over medium heat for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Occasionally skim the foam off of the top.

steps.headline: Stir in:
steps.description: 2 teaspoons of powdered saffron in warm water 1 cup of white sugar 1/4 cup of canola oil 1/3 cup of rosewater.

steps.headline: Cover the mixture.
steps.description: Simmer on low heat for 45 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the lid of the saucepan.
Stir until the mixture begins to look like a thick pudding-like cream.
steps.description: All the water should be boiled out at this point.

steps.headline: Add more saffron to taste (optional).
Add the blanched slivered almonds (optional).
Cook over medium-low heat until a pudding-like texture develops (approximately 30 more minutes).
Remove the pot from the stove once the mixture has thickened.
Pour the sholeh zard slowly into a large, shallow plate.
Decorate with the cinnamon and pistachios in a pretty pattern.
steps.description: Do this once the top has dried into a thin, yet hard, layer.

steps.headline: Cover the plate once the mixture has cooled.
steps.description: Place it into the refrigerator to continue chilling until the pudding has transformed into a jello-like consistency. The pudding also tastes great warm (right after it is done cooking).

steps.headline: Finished.

text: Preparation Cover the uncooked rice with warm water in a pot.  Stir the rice gently in the water. Stirring helps to remove some of the starch and grit Rinse and drain the rice several times, until the water runs clear.  Drain the washed rice.  Place the rice in a non-stick saucepan with 10 cups of water and a 1/4 teaspoon of salt.  Place the saffron into 2 tablespoons of warm water and set aside to infuse.  Cooking Cover the rice with a lid.  Bring the rice to a boil over medium heat for 20 minutes. Occasionally skim the foam off of the top. Stir in: 2 teaspoons of powdered saffron in warm water 1 cup of white sugar 1/4 cup of canola oil 1/3 cup of rosewater. Cover the mixture. Simmer on low heat for 45 minutes. Remove the lid of the saucepan.  Stir until the mixture begins to look like a thick pudding-like cream. All the water should be boiled out at this point. Add more saffron to taste (optional).  Add the blanched slivered almonds (optional).  Cook over medium-low heat until a pudding-like texture develops (approximately 30 more minutes).  Remove the pot from the stove once the mixture has thickened.  Finishing Up and Serving Pour the sholeh zard slowly into a large, shallow plate. Let it cool. Decorate with the cinnamon and pistachios in a pretty pattern. Do this once the top has dried into a thin, yet hard, layer. Cover the plate once the mixture has cooled. Place it into the refrigerator to continue chilling until the pudding has transformed into a jello-like consistency. The pudding also tastes great warm (right after it is done cooking). Finished.
